title: Confusing error message on trait bound not satisfied with supertraits

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

body:
I'm not sure about my interpretation but the message is for me a little confusing. I've reproduced a minimal case. In the following code, there is a missing implementation of the trait A for the structure S.

[Link to the playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=3876b71cd084f1e607eb81cd758dd301)

```rust
trait A {}

trait B: A {}
impl<T> A for T where T: B {}

trait C: A {}

struct S {}
impl C for S {}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0277]: the trait bound `S: B` is not satisfied
 --> src/main.rs:9:6
  |
9 | impl C for S {}
  |      ^ the trait `B` is not implemented for `S`
  |
note: required for `S` to implement `A`
 --> src/main.rs:4:9
  |
4 | impl<T> A for T where T: B {}
  |         ^     ^
note: required by a bound in `C`
 --> src/main.rs:6:10
  |
6 | trait C: A {}
  |          ^ required by this bound in `C`
```

I don't think the Trait B should appear in the error message. 
Ideally the output should look like:

```
the trait bound `S: A` is not satisfied
 --> src/main.rs:9:6
  |
9 | impl C for S {}
  |      ^ the trait `A` is not implemented for `S`
  |
note: required for `S` to implement `A`
 --> src/main.rs:4:9
  |
6 | trait C: A {}
  |          ^ required by this bound in `C`
```
I've tried the stable version: 1.61 and the nightly 1.66 on the playground with the same result. I've seen other issues on confusing error messages on traits but I don't think there are related to this one.
